importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the public announcement of Pakistan's first hyperspectral satellite launch, signaling a major advancement in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The event occurred in 2025, placing it within a broader global context of emerging space technologies and national space programs expanding in the 2020s.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a significant milestone in its space program.
The satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
H1 is capable of detecting subtle chemical or material changes on the ground, enabling applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster response.
The satellite will support national goals such as precision agriculture, climate resilience, and efficient management of natural resources.
The mission enhances Pakistan’s capacity to identify geohazard risks, contributing to development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
Pakistan’s space program has expanded rapidly, with three satellites (H1, EO-1, and KS-1) launched this year, with EO-1 and KS-1 already fully operational.
H1 is expected to take about two months to calibrate before full operational status is achieved.
The launch reflects Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technology development.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the subject of the article, as it launched its first hyperspectral satellite, demonstrating national progress in space technology and self-reliance in critical monitoring systems.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the organization responsible for the launch and management of Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, H1, and is central to the country’s space program development.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the technological centerpiece of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation capabilities for agriculture, disaster monitoring, and environmental management.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site in China’s northwest is crucial because it highlights Pakistan’s reliance on international collaboration for space launches, particularly with China.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is relevant due to its role as the host of the launch site and a key partner in Pakistan’s space cooperation, reflecting geopolitical and technological interdependence.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development linking Xinjiang and Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s geohazard monitoring capabilities are expected to support CPEC by enhancing infrastructure safety and environmental assessment in sensitive regions.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other operational satellites launched by Pakistan in 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They demonstrate the broader expansion of Pakistan’s space program and provide context for H1 as a follow-up to earlier successful missions.

namedEntities.name: Hyperspectral satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of satellite capable of detecting fine material and chemical changes on Earth’s surface
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This technology is central to the article’s purpose, enabling superior monitoring in agriculture, environmental science, and disaster response compared to traditional satellites.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, through its space agency SUPARCO. This marks a major advancement in the nation’s space capabilities, enabling advanced Earth observation for agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster management, and urban planning. The satellite, which can detect subtle chemical changes on the ground, is expected to enhance national resilience and contribute to development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 will take about two months to calibrate before full operations, it is part of a broader trend of Pakistan’s space program growth, with two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) already operational. The launch underscores the strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration and technology development.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
